description:
A card game based on the stories of Marten Toonder's Tom Poes and Oliver B. Bommel. Players have to create a path placing road cards numbering from 1 to 7 in ascending order. The goal is to reach the #7 card (Treasure "De Schat") first.

There is 1 deck of cards that all players draw from, containing the road cards and several other cards to prevent other players from getting to the treasure or assist you in your own effort to find the treasure first.

Object of the game: Keep possession of Play-cards by remembering exactly where the 12 images are hidden. 12 different images are hidden under blue 'caps' During the game they move from one place to another. The oldest player starts this game. Throw the dice en move your pon over the track on the board. Execute the command which is stated by an pictogram. You either have to point out the right and exact location of the number or image that is stated on the track. The tricky thing is that the caps move around the board as a result of some orders. Some orders on the track are simple, and need you to pin point 1 image or number. Other orders force yoy to point out for example, 3 fruits or 3 figures. Every player has 3-7 playcards. everytime they slip out during the game by not pointing out the right items, they loose one playcard (it is flipped to the stop-side). The player who keeps at least one card in play while the others are played out, wins the game.

Originally published in Panzerfaust Magazine Volume 5 #5 in September 1970,Poltawa a game covering the 18th Century battle between the Swedes and the Russians on June 28, 1709 designed by Chris Johnson.

These early issues of Panzerfaust were mimeographed and all the components were printed in the magazine, more of a game kit.

You could not actually use the original components without destroying parts of the magazine that were on the other side of the page, in some cases components of the the game - i.e. maps and counters printed on the reverse side of the rules.

The 2.5-pages of rules are in excellent condition (relies heavily on AH classic rules such as Waterloo) and include the historical orders of battle.

Content:
64 round wooden sticks, 1 wooden box

The aim of this game of skill is to build a tower out of the round sticks, in order to make as many points as possible with the value of the sticks.

Content:
35 picture cards, 7 colored wooden plates

You may know all animals and saw some already. Do you know though how those animals are born and how they grow up.
All 35 picture cards are laid face down on the table.
Now everyone tries to find the cards of every animal in the row of 1-5 and to lay it down aside a wooden plate. The player with the last picture card aside the wooden plate gets the plate. The most plates determines the winner.

The Rugby Addicts Board Game by Gren has arrived. A fantastic game from the much loved and world famous Gren. Take a drop kick, Six Nations Teams, scrum down boys win that ball! Designed by the man himself and made entirely in the UK.

Features:

Contains all the facets of the real game - passing, moving with the ball, kicks, tackling, scrums, ricks and lineouts.

A special kicking device called - The Boot - is included for kicking the ball over the posts.

The game includes a DVD tutorial so no need to plough through countless pages of instructions.

All the fun of the real game without the pain!

Game comes from Hassenfeld Bros. the precursor of Hasbro. The box cover states that the object of the game is to "Help G.I.Joe knock out the enemy machine gun nest. Game comes with 16 pawns and some game cards. From Games Gone By.

"Stay or Go"

This is a fairly basic roll-and-move aimed to teach children color recognition and set collection.

The game board is a spiral-shaped worm divided in coloured segments (4 colours/black with number/white). Players start in the head and move towards the tail. Landing on a coloured space gives the player one counter (quarter) of that colour; landing on a white has no effect; and landing on a black space causes the player to lose a number of quarters, the colors chosen by player.

Quarters collected during the game are scored when all players have either finished or dropped out. Quarters forming a circle of a single colour score the most, quarters forming multi-coloured circles score less, while left-over quarters score least.

During the game, there are four chances to drop out, identified by the grey shaded areas. This may make sense because the numbers in the black segments increase towards the end, and a player that has collected a good set of circles may want to cut her losses rather than carry on.  
(This is the sole tactical choice in the game.)

Paletti game no. 4065

The game consists of 50 cards comprising 22 service cards and 28 play cards. The service cards dictate whether the service is to the backhand, forehand an ace or a fault. The play cards are made up of 5 each of the 4 combinations of backhand/forehand to backhand/forehand and 4 smash and 4 lob cards. Scoring is the same as in lawn tennis. The two packs (service and play) are shuffled and both players receive 4 play cards to form their hand. The server then places the top service card face up to show the type of serve. An ace is a point immediately won and if a fault is drawn then another card is immediately drawn and if this is another fault, the point is lost. If it is any of the other service cards, the opponent can return it only if he has a corresponding card that allows him to play the return type or he can play a lob card. A lob card can only be returned by another lob card or a smash card. A smash can only be returned by a lob. If a player cannot return with the appropriate card then he loses that point. Players replace cards as they are played from the draw deck to make a 4 card hand. Play continues until the correct number of sets (predetermined at the start) is won.

"Suspicion" is a detective game set in the times of the legendary private-eye Sherlock Holmes.
The playing board represents London.
Each player is a detective whose aim is to solve the crimes of three suspects. There are 24 suspects in all.  Each of these bears the name of a fictional Victorian criminal and four items of information.  These are:
1. a clue to identification
2. evidence of the crime
3. proof (fingerprint)
4. a district of London
To solve the crime, the detective must collect every item of information on the card.

The Party Game That's Survival of the Fastest!

Slap-N-Grab is a fast-paced free-for-all where opponents spring into action slapping down and grabbing cards based on colors, counts and cartoon creatures. All the animal cards are dealt out. Cards have 1, 2 or 3 colored animals on them: elephants, rhinos, kangaroos, monkeys or cows. Two Slap Cards are played face up, for example "Four Cows" and "Three red monkeys." Players then sequentially flip over animal cards until exactly 4 cows or 3 red monkeys appear among them all. At that moment, players race to slap the corresponding Slap Card and win the round, taking the slap card as a prize and turning over another one. If you make a mistake and the required animals are not showing, you must return a previously won card to the bottom of the slap deck. When the slap deck is gone, players count how many they have won and the player with the most wins.

In Dry Gulch Junction, the players are erecting buildings in the titular town. Each player has a set of Building cards with the Buildings they may construct during the game. Additionally, there is a deck of Improvement cards which have two uses. The first is as an Improvement to your existing Buildings. These Improvements can be the second or third story addition to a Building already constructed. However, the other use of the cards are through the Claims printed at the top of the card. Twice each turn, an Improvement card can be set aside for all players to use as a Claim for money. The Claims allow all players to take money into their general construction fund or to set aside a larger sum of money to improve a specific Building. The player who most efficiently manages their resources and constructs the best Buildings in town will win the game.

The Game of Politics, or The Race For the Presidency was first published in 1887 and patented in 1888. Unlike the later game of the same name by Oswald B. Lord, candidates in this game play cards against each other to reach the office of Mayor, Governor, Congressman, and Senator before moving on to a battle over each state's Electoral votes for the U.S. Presidency. 201 votes out of the 401 for all of the states are required to win.

While the game is listed as being for 2, 4 or 6 players, in fact there are only two candidates competing for the Presidency. When there are more than two players, the sides form two teams that play in turn to advance their respective candidates.

Few intact copies of the game seem to have survived to the present day. However, the patent application -- which lists the game's rules -- and surviving game boards give a good indication as to what the components were for the W.S. Reed Toy Company's release. These include:


     Rules
     Game board
     Two "wads" (pawns) to move on the board's tracks; one red, one blue
     23 pins for use in the left and right columns
     At least one pin to mark the last bypassed state during the first pass through the state list
     A deck of 48 cards, containing eight each of the following values: 1000, 2000, 3000, 5000, 7000, and 10000.

Druid’s Duel is a quick-playing card game. In Druid’s Duel, you’re a druid competing with other druids in a shape changing contest to display your wits and prowess. The druid who best adapts to the tactics of his or her opponents becomes the new head of the Circle.

Everyone starts the game with a full had of strategy cards. Each round you secretly pick a shape (lion, peacock, or jackrabbit) and a strategy card to play. When shapes are revealed, you may or may not get to discard your strategy card, depending on the shapes and strategies of your opponents.

If you’re a Jackrabbit, you succeed if you played the lowest strategy card.  If you’re a Lion, you succeed if you played the highest strategy card.  If you’re a Peacock, you succeed if no one else played a card that matches your card’s rank or suit.  If you’re the first one to discard all of your strategy cards, you win.

Druid’s Duel is a game for two to four players. Druid’s Duel uses a standard Poker deck. You can read the rules at http://www.invisible-city.com/play/470. A four-player game takes about 30 minutes to play. Druid’s Duel is appropriate for ages 13 and up.

Aniolowie is Polish CCG. It is about the war of Angels fighting in order to gain the human spirits. Aniolowie has got unique, especially created universe. There are plans for first expansion and Role Playing Game.

Homepage: www.gusla.eu

Based on the classic but short-lived television show of the same name.

Object of game: Luke Parry and his cowboys at the Bar-X Ranch are battling an outlaw gang of cattle rustlers for controls of the range. Each side is equally matched. The first side to capture all the enemy’s men or reach the enemy’s “Finish Space” with 2 men is the winner, but it takes luck, pluck and skill to win.

Ambush is an abstract strategy game for 2 players. Two Icehouse stashes and 4 Martian Coasters are needed, one per player. Players will either play one of their 15 pyramids on the board or set a pyramid aside to rotate a coaster. Either action may allow them to capture a pyramid belonging to their opponent.

Game System

    Icehouse Pieces

Battlez FMX is an action sports based collectible card & dice game, featuring Freestyle Motocross superstar Brian Deegan, along with Metal Mulisha team members Todd Potter & Jeremy Lusk.

Battlez FMX allows you to battle it out as if in a real freestyle MX
competition, playing as your favorite FMX rider. Score or take points away from your opponent by matching dice combinations on the cards and  executing tricks like Kiss of Death's, BackFlip's, Cliffhangers, Rock Solids and more. First player to 100 points wins.

In addition, there are specialty cards such as the Rockstar Energy Drink Boost Card allowing you to roll all 3 dice at once, the Stop Card allowing you to stop your opponent from playing the same card repeatedly and the First Aid Card, immediately subtracting 50 points from your opponent.

"Trip for Spain" it's a game for Ages 8 and up

It stimulates the sense of the planning, introduces in the geography of Spain and in the knowledge of its cities and places of tourist interest.

The quality of the images contributes to the aesthetic education. It favors the social education, as collective game.

Travel for plane and by sea for all the localities of Spain before your opponents!

Players take turns discarding cards to represent the throw of a bowling ball with up to two throws per frame - the goal is to get all 10 pins in each frame either with a "strike" (get all 10 pins at once by playing one card) or by finishing off the unclaimed pins on the second card with a "spare".

Each game consists of 10 frames, and the game is scored via regulation American bowling rules. A "Captain" player keeps score on a laminated scoresheet for all players. With 2+ players, the player with the highest score at the end of 10 frames wins.  With solo play, you try to beat your previous best score. The highest possible score is 300 points!

The original (1960) edition contained two decks of cards (108 total), enough for 1 to 4 players to play right out of the box. The 1964 edition came with only one deck of 54 cards supporting either one or two players unless you purchased a second set of 54 cards separately to allow play with up to 4 people (the laminated scorecard in both versions includes 4 player lines to support up to four players).

Trivia: The yellow 1964 "Authorized Edition" box shows the game named "Don Carter's Strike! Bowling Game" and doesn't mention "300" anywhere on the box, but the instructions only refer to the game as "300" and don't mention Don Carter anywhere! The most likely reason is that they licensed Don's endorsement for the 1964 edition of the game but neglected to update the rules sheet to accommodate the newer name. Don was and is (apparently) widely considered the greatest bowler of all time.

The game is about 20 inches long, 14 inches wide, 1 1/2 inches deep. There is a lid which slides out through the top end to reveal the playing board inside. There are yellow wood slats and  blue slats that connect to them to  let them slide up & down. Some versions of the game come with red wood paddles which are 8  inches long with 2 different length yellow pegs attached which fit into the holes along the sides, but not all versions have this.  The game comes with a wooden dowel over 18 inches long and two small steel balls with etched symbols on them. The goal of the game is to move the ball down through the tipped slats so that it ends up going through the 150 metal loop at the bottom in order to score maximum points for your turn.
From Whitman and Walt Disney Productions, this 1975 children's game is won by the first player to play all of their balloon discs onto the balloon circles.

Similar to The Monopoly Game and The Mad Magazine Game. Published by the Swedish MAD Magazine department as a supplement in the Swedish MAD Magazine (Svenska MAD) No. 4 1976. It was later reissued as a supplement in Svenska MAD´s stora julpajare 1982.

From the Heresy Miniatures website

"Deathball is a popular gladiatorial pit-fighting variant that is played mainly in the Kingdom of Morica, ruled by Dark Duke Henry the Red, also known by his official title of Duke Scaldis II."

My description:

A game of fantasy mayhem loosely based on football, or maybe some ancient religious game from the Aztecs. Mayhem with miniatures, dice and strategy.

In the same family as Blood Bowl and Futbowel

Rules and board can be downloaded free for personal use at http://www.heresyminiatures.com/deathball.htm
A tiddly winks variant based on tennis, played on a cloth game board.

Sport Of Kings Challenge: The Horse Racing Quiz Game

"4400 questions to entertain followers of the world's #1 spectator sport!"

"A party game! A study guide! A nostalgia trip!"

This horse racing trivia game includes a colorful race track board, 6 plastic horses, 6 plastic tokens, hundreds of trivia question cards, a die, and 6 category cards.

Players answer equine trivia questions as they move their horses around the track.

(c)1986 Kuriakos Inc.

A game of luck, intuition and barefaced bluff. You have one simple task - get rid of the "Killer Balls" while keeping the highest value "Golden Balls" in play.
Vote out your opponents in the first 2 rounds (1 round in 3-player play), to make it to the "Bin or Win", and choose your "Golden Five" jackpot balls.
Face your last remaining opponent in a tense head-to-head to "Split or Steal".

Another Franchise to the movie of the same name, this time in the small BMM-Box.
The players move stacks of character tokens and try to reveal certain characters on the finish line, while avoiding the villain

The year is 1692. In an atmosphere of pessimism and charged paranoia, the citizens of Salem are at the mercy of demons – not demons of the soul, but demons of the mind. What began as a devout Puritan community devolved in a matter of months into a people torn apart by fear, lies, and fanatical orthodoxy. The residents of Salem quickly discovered that they could find Hell all around them.

Salem incites the atmosphere of paranoia that held the village of Salem captive. Players act with the assumption that there are witches among them (and, in this case, there will be). Each player controls six residents of Salem, three of whom are witches. Game play is simple: try to rid the village of witches and keep the identities of your own residents secret.

The game plays over the course of four rounds representing the four months (June–September 1692) in which the hysteria was at its height. Each round has two parts: a Witch Hunt and a Witch Trial, followed by hangings (the dates of which correspond to the four actual hangings that took place in Salem that year). During the Witch Hunt, players send residents to jail and provide alibis for their own jailed citizens. At the end of each round all jailed citizens stand trial. Players then collectively decide who is hanged and who is spared. The player who is most successful at discerning witches from villagers wins!

While the story surrounding the Salem witch trials has become something of a legend, every character in this game is based on a real person whose life was directly touched and in some cases torn apart or taken away by the events surrounding the Salem witch trials. Extensive research has been done to craft the real-life stories of all 42 residents in the game.

While this game focuses on the people and events specific to Salem, Massachusetts, similar witch hunts were taking place as far north as Maine and as far West as Connecticut. Surely, the devil had come to New England.

A 1939 wargame that is very rare and (if you can find it) very expensive.  The board features a very colorful map of Europe, with France, Italy, Germany, and England's player areas in the corners of the board.

From the publisher:

Galáxia S.A. is an exciting game where player will build an intergalactic economical empire! The players will dispute every single piece of the galaxy by acquiring the right to explore planets that produce several goods. These are to be sold at the intergalactic market. But the galaxy is a dangerous place and your opponents will use cunning and intrigue to make your journey harder. Come aboard this adventure and become the most successful cosmic tycoon!

Galáxia S.A. is played in turns that are composed of the following phases:

Action Phase 
Purchase of technology 
Resources Generation Phase 
Exploration Phase 
Planets Auction Phase

With a fresh look and a high replay value, the game will give players hours of fun.

Galáxia S.A. é um emocionante jogo de construção de um império econômico estelar! Os jogadores disputam cada pedaço da galáxia, adquirindo o direito de exploração de planetas que produzem diversos bens e devem vendê-los no mercado intergaláctico. Mas a galáxia é um lugar perigoso, e seus adversários usarão de artimanhas e intrigas para atrapalhar a sua jornada... Então embarque nessa odisséia para tornar-se o mais bem sucedido magnata cósmico!

Galáxia S.A. é jogado em turnos que são compostos pelas seguintes fases:

Fase de Ação 
Compra de tecnologia
Fase de Geração de Recursos 
Fase de Exploração
Fase de Leilão de Planetas

Com um visual inovador e com uma alta rejogabilidade, o jogo proporcionará aos jogadores horas de diversão.


Cosmic Mogul is a non-collectible card game for 3-4 players. During the game, players become cosmic moguls, searching the galaxy for new worlds to exploit as they build their economic empire one planet at a time.

Illustrated by Michael Christopher.
Brazilian Version Illustrated by Marcelo Bissoli

Home Page: http://www.riachuelogames.com.br/galaxia/


Magnata Cósmico é um jogo sobre comércio interplanetário e compra de planetas. Os jogadores podem comprar planetas, negociar bens a comprar tecnologias, criando um império econômico. De 3 a 4 jogadores.

A Arte e o Design/Gráfico por Michael Christopher.
Versão Brasileira Ilustrada por Marcelo Bissoli

"Irány a játszótér!" means "Let's go to the playground!".
This is a classic Hungarian children's game from the mid 1980s.
It's a simple roll and move game where you have to visit all the games in a playground.
A very old and rare Walt Disney game, which also have unusual game mechanics for a Disney-game. The players shall collect gold, and also steal gold from each other and try to hide their  own gold.

Each player asks another player for a city card, and if he has it he has to hand it over. The goal is to complete as many sets as possible (each set corresponds to a province, and contains a varying number of cities).

This is a rare children's game, probably published in the early 1900s.  The cover features some children and animals jumping over hurdles.  The board has a track circling the outside of the board with a picture of a band playing on the green interior of the track.  Also on the interior of the track are four cheering adults, a tepee, and a table set for dinner (with lobster being served).

From the publisher's web site:
"The new dimension in dungeon-games

Gruftmeister Adventure says goodbye to dice and chance-oriented fighting-systems. Here you fight the undead with your skill.

Up to four players explore the crypt of count Gramwuml in search for treasure. Behind every door there's fear: Go to the arena and fight. Playing a cryptrunner, thief, fighter or magician, you try to beat the other players. But even when there's no other player, Gruftmeister Adventure can be played as a solo-adventure.

Players start at the skeleton of count Gramwuml. From there they explore the crypt room by room, adding new floor tiles. Use actions to explore the crypt, open doors, fight undead or cast spells. Once you encounter a closed door or a coffin, you go to the arena and fight with your skills. A real challenge for both younger and older players. Finally no more orgies of throwing dice.

Gruftmeister Adventure is a totally new game, you don't need an older version of Gruftmeister. Everything needed for the adventure is included: 18 floor-tiles for all-new adventures every time, 140 cards for monsters, treasures, doors, spells, more than 100 wooden pieces, the fighting arena with all the parts for thrilling duels."

Re-implements:

    Gruftmeister
Actually a spin and move game from Cadaco from 1954. The game includes a pictorial peg board, a Mother Hubbard spinner and 16 wooden pegs (4 each in 4 different colors)

Pre-Emptive Strike! is a board game for 2 to 6 players in which each player controls one of the factions warring for control of the desert region of Iraghania. Pre-Emptive Strike! is a tongue-in-cheek look at our world’s current leaders and the problems they can all create.

The Pre-Emptive Strike! download, print, and play game contains over 700 full color tokens, a huge board game map, scenarios, faction tiles, and two full 56 card decks of event cards. All you need to bring to the table are the dice.

SuDoku: Die Spielesammlung is a set of six games which use similar Sudoku-like rules to govern placement of tiles.

In each game, players have identical sets of tiles (numbered 1-9 multiple times) and each turn play one which is randomly drawn. Certain defined sections of the board can only have one of each number in them. When each of certain small sections of the board is filled, the tiles for each player in the section are totaled and points given for first and second place. Bonus points are also given for players who complete larger board sections. The sections which define the placement constraints, regular scoring, and bonus scoring vary from game to game.

The six games are:

1. Classic-SuDoku, played on the standard 9x9 grid.

2. Labyrinth-SuDoku, played on a board divided into nine irregular nine-square sections.

3. Killer-SuDoku, played on a board divided into many small sections.

4. Kakuro, played on a 9x9 grid interrupted by numbered squares. This game can be played two ways - in one version the numbered squares provide an additional constraint and way to earn bonus points.

5. 3D-SuDoku, played on a board which depicts three faces of a cube, giving eight-space rows in three directions.

6. Hexa-SuDoku, played on a board divided into nine regions of nine hexagons each.

From the publisher:

Mutants and Death Ray Guns is a fast-paced, skirmish level, post-holocaust, science fantasy miniature system for two or more players. Based on the popular Song of Blades and Heroes mechanics, the rules are simple and, above all, FUN.

After 200 years of war with nuclear and biochemical weapons, new races compete for supremacy over a scorched Earth. Pit your band of after-the-bomb desperadoes, mutant humanoids, sentient plants, robots, androids, hyper-evolved animals and zombie-like Wretched against the dangers of a wasted world.  Face irradiated terrain, contagious diseases, aggressive life forms and malfunctioning equipment. Collect artifacts, find food, fight over scarce pools of uncontaminated water, and save your resources, because in the harsh post-apocalypse world every energy cell, every ration and every drop of water means the difference between life and death.

Have you got what it takes to survive?

Designed for fast-play, you can finish a battle in 30-45 minutes; play a mini-campaign in one evening!

Play with any single-based miniature, in any scale.
Inexpensive and Convenient: play with as little as four miniatures per player. The game requires little space -- a 2'x2' table is enough!
Uses three sticks for easy measurement of movement and ranges!
Includes five factions: Humans, Androids, Mutants, Robots, Mutated Plants, Mutated Animals, and the disease-ridden Wretched!
40 pre-generated characters to start playing immediately and six scenarios included.
Complete rules for physical and mental mutations along with rules for power armor, high-tech weapons and psionic powers!
Campaign Rules: your characters become better fighters, gain new mutations and equipment after every battle.
Also includes a list of manufacturers of suitable miniatures.

Note: this is a complete, stand alone product. Purchase of Song of Blades and Heroes is not necessary.

Sauve qui poux is the third game from young French publisher L'Auberge des Jeux.
(The title is a word play in French that bases on "every man for himself ").

Description by publisher:
Caution: Completely delirious lice unload on an innocent head!

Use with relevance competences of your army - queen, workers, infantry, rifleman and chemists - to keep the supremacy of your colony.

Collect barrels of blood and play your action cards wisely.

Will you be able to lay enough nits and to protect them? Will you manage to occupy the gameboard strategically?
Solo or in teams, take the command of your units and make your adversaries bite the dust.

A small gift game sold at English heritage sights which feature castles, abbeys or some medieval history,

Game box comes with 5 pewter Knights from different ages in history, games is very basic get from one side of a slim checkered board to the other, one player has 4 figures the other player just 1.

from the back of the box:
This period in history relates to what was is know as the high middle ages, the three centuries between 1100 and 1485. the church was at the center of medieval life and castles where strongholds as well as centers of law and government. In the C11th and the C12th large numbers of knights left England for the religious wars of the crusades to the holy land. by the 1300s more than 1500 castles had been built throughout the land knights had more peaceful interests. Heraldry was the order of the day and the rules of chivalry; Tournaments of Arms and jousting were popular pastimes.

IAGO Chess is unique in its nature. The best way to view IAGO Chess is a system used to manage the wide range of interests on the part of people who like to play, and an approach to acclimate new players to the system.
Because of this, you won't find one set of codified rules, as you would with other chess games. The IAGO Chess system accomplishes its objectives by the use of multiple versions (classes) of the game that represent the fullness of the chess experience. These versions build upon one another,
to allow a person to get fully familiar with the game. There are six versions (classes) of the game. These versions are: A-Class, B-Class, C-Class, M-Class, V-Class, and X-Class.

This version of chess is more than just a chess variant, it is a system by which chess can integrate variants and evolve.  It has multiple layers and is robust enough to change over time.  Its mission is to be a forever evolving version of chess that will provide a migration path for changes.

It is also meant as a framework for playing all versions of chess relating to the International Abstract Games Organization.

For the actual rules, check out the Chess Variants website:
http://www.chessvariants.org/index/msdisplay.php?itemid=MSiagochesssyste
To be the first player to place all of his candle pieces on the candle holder and then place the flame on the top of the candle.

The book consists of over a thousand moral dilemmas in the form of questions. A turn consists of a player answering a question from the book by secretly voting either 'yes' or 'no'. The other players must try to correctly guess that players' answer. A short discussion is allowed between the other players. Once all other players have made guess, each scores one point if correctly determining the questioned players answer . The player taking the turn will only score one point if there is a majority or equal number of other players that correctly guessed his/her answer.

The object of the game is to be the first player to move any one of his "men" from his home base all around the game field and back to his home base.
Game Components:
Base
Game field
Flippers
Label sheet
Steel ball
Bumpers
Men

In this solitaire cyberspace Piecepack game you move your icebreakers across the ice in search of the four Data Forts. Once located, you have to infiltrate the Forts with the corresponding color icebreaker. Just make sure you don't use all your strength before you have succeeded doing this, or you'll die from brain damage!!!

(From the Introduction to the Witchlord rulebook)

Witchlord is the natural adaptation of fantasy role gaming converted into a board game. There is a distinct advantage to fantasy role gaming from a board; and that is it gets rid of the need for a Game Master or scenario creator. The board, cards and matrix tables contain all the information necessary and the dice determine the outcome of your adventure. No human arbitrator is necessary.

All the passages, rooms, treasure and monsters are randomly generated. This makes no two adventures ever the same. Each time you enter the Witchlord's Castle you can expect a completely different scenario stocked with new treasure and monsters. As the player moves around the board, he will receive information about the configurations of the Witchlord's Castle. This will enable the player to plot his progress on the graph paper given.

The player will choose one of the six Adventure Classes to play. this determines the player's spell and weapon capability.

The player's objective in the game is to collect proficiency points. This is done by the slaying of monsters and the collection of treasure. Encounters and treasure are dictated by the playing cards and matrix tables. When the player reaches the 10th stratum or proficiency level, he must do battle with one of the Witchlord's generals. If the General is vanquished, the the player has won and earned safe passage out of Witchlord's Castle.

The Witchlord Game can be played as a single scenario, or as a campaign game.
Be the first player or team to collect 6 Bible coins by answering questions correctly. Includes 500 cards with 2000 questions.

Content: board, 10 pawns, 2 dice

This is the exciting race of two "Bit-Schaften" of 5 bits each across the Bitmoor.
The aim of the game is to reach the opposite side with all 5 bits despite all obstacles and put them together in a row.
